properties.Name: Callan Meadows
properties.Description:
The Callan Meadow holds the distinction of being the first site (in 2015) on our campuses where we trialed a “don’t mow let it grow” approach. It was also the first site on campus where we adopted the guidelines from the National Biodiversity Data Centre’s All Ireland Pollinator Plan. This was crucially important to visually demonstrate the benefits and importance of biodiversity and that a departure from the usual management approaches of regular mowing which resulted in very few flowering plants across our campus. Within a year the site had an abundance of flowering plants such as clover, dandelions, creeping buttercup and self heal. In 2018 we were delighted to find a number of pyramidal and rare bee orchids which were never before reported at that site due to the old management practices. For a recent survey of the plants and insects on this site please see the following link.

Currently the campus has 93,000 m2 of our grounds managed for biodiversity.

Unfortunately, much of the meadow was used for the site offices when the new TSI building was being constructed. However, the meadow is now returning to its former glory once again.

properties.Name: Arts & Hume Corridor
properties.Description:
One of the main plazas of the university is located outside the Hume, Iontas, Eolas, Arts and Science buildings. We have been very fortunate to be able to develop this area into a low maintenance meadow in such a central location, frequented by the majority of our students. A number of grassed areas are managed under the don’t mow let it grow approach and each are only mown regularly around the edges. It was our experiences that a regular 3-4 inch cut was excellent for encouraging low flowering plants. The site is rich in clover, yarrow, creeping buttercup, dandelions and daisies and there are a number of trees including lime trees, conifers, maple, cherry trees and lime. For a full list of our recent survey on this area please see the following link.

In 2019 a number of pollinator friendly planter boxes containing lavender were installed in addition to four beds that were planted with native Irish wildflower seed mixes.

properties.Name: Courtyard Meadows
properties.Description:
This courtyard meadow was one of the first areas on the campus that was designated for wildflower meadow development and is one of our actions for pollinators as part of the NBDC’s All Ireland Pollinator Plan. The site became available when the new Courtyard Apartments were built and it was decided in 2017 to plant the available areas with wildflower seed mixes details of which can be found here.

Over the past number of years, the site has developed well and is rich in X, Y and Z plant species and has an abundance of visiting pollinators including bumblebees, hoverflies and butterflies. For a recent survey of the bumblebees see the following link.

In 2021 some of the meadow was used to house an outdoor gym including a basketball net, exercise equipment and exercise area.

Mowing plan: Cut once a year usually in October. Allowed to grow for the entire season with minimal interference

Herbicide use: 2023- Weed Control on Hard surfaces via Acetic Acid

Some nice finds

properties.Name: AstroPitch Meadow
properties.Description:
In 2019 the AstroPitch meadow was developed from a small woodland that had to be cleared to improve visibility for traffic that used the road in both directions. This work was conducted under consultation with a qualified ecologist. A 60m stand of Hawthorne was left after the clearing which now provides excellent forage for hoverflies and solitary bees in Spring and berries for birds.

The site was allowed to naturally regenerate and is now abundant in Dock, Yorkshire fog, Ragwort and Cocksfoot. Ox-Eye Daisy, Cowslip and Yarrow are also abundant and are thought to have established from seed blown in from the Apartment Courtyard Meadow that was planted with native wildflower mixes. For recent surveys of the plants found at this site see the following link.

The site is a stop on the North Campus Biodiversity Loop and the MU Bumblebee monitoring Route. For a recent survey of the bumblebees see the following link.

Mowing plan: Cut roughly every 6 – 8 weeks to a height of 5- 6 inches. Final cut of the meadow occurs in Sept/Oct time.

Some nice finds

properties.Name: Phoenix Meadow & Plaza
properties.Description:
The meadow and plaza at the front of the Phoenix restaurant and sports hall offer a mix of areas managed for biodiversity. these include a small, grassed area which is cut every 6-8 weeks to a height of 5-6 inches. This mowing regime has resulted in the meadow becoming extremely rich in clovers (purple and white) which support a diversity of insects during the summer particular the common carder bee Bombus pascuorum. A number of bee orchids were found on the site in 2019.

The plaza has a number of raised beds that are planted with laurel and lavender which support bees, hoverflies and butterflies and has another raised lawn that has several trees. The raise lawn is mown every 6-8 weeks. The edges of this area were traditionally spayed with glyphosate which exposed the soil on the south facing bank. This encouraged a large aggregation of a number of species of mining bees (Andrena spp). However, with the reduction of chemical pesticide use across the campus the bank has become dominated by grasses and the number of solitary bees and their nests has been greatly reduced. This highlights an important aspect of grounds management, in that the actions that we think are beneficial may have negative consequences. Research is planned to determine sustainable and environmentally friendly ways to expose the bank to promote mining bee colonisations once again. For a survey of the plants and insects found at this site please see the following link.

The site is a part of the Bumblebee monitoring route. For a view of recent bumblebees recorded here see the following link.

Mowing plan: Cut roughly every 6 – 8 weeks to a height of 5- 6 inches. Final cut of the meadow occurs in Sept/Oct time.

properties.Name: Student Union Meadows
properties.Description:
The area adjacent to the SU carpark is an extensive and rich natural habitat that incorporates a small mixed deciduous woodland, with medium and high canopies that transitions into a wildflower meadow. Trees that are found here include Hawthorn, Birch, Oak, Conifers, Sycamore, Lime, Holly and some apple trees. The meadow is rich in creeping buttercup, cow parsley, clover, yarrow, cuckoo flowers, all of which support a vibrant pollinator community. For the results of our recent surveys please see the following link.

The rich biodiversity in the area makes it an excellent site for training and teaching ecological surveying and plant identification to Biology and Science Education undergraduate students. The meadow is also a stop on the North Campus bumblebee monitoring trail (see link for recent bee survey results).

Mowing plan:Cut once in September/October. An access path has been mowed through the site.

Nice Finds

properties.Name: TSI Frontage
properties.Description:
One of the newest buildings on the campus is the Technology, Society and Innovation (TSI) Building, which opened in 2021. It was the first building at MU where the landscaping was designed using native Irish flora and with biodiversity in mind. The hedging is native Irish hedging and a number of native Irish trees (Scotts pine and silver birch) have been planted around the building.

In addition to a number of ornamental pollinator friendly plant beds, bug hotels and lawn areas which are mown every 6 weeks, the front of the TSI is planted with pollinator friendly bulbs (crocus, allium, daffodils and wood anemone) that flower in early Spring to providing food to early emerging pollinators such as hibernating bumblebees queens.

Mowing plan: Cut roughly every 6 – 8 weeks to a height of 5- 6 inches. Final cut of the meadow occurs in Sept/Oct time.

properties.Name: Kilcock Rd Woodland & Meadow
properties.Description:
At the front of the North Campus, along the Kilcock road, there is a very nice mixed, predominantly deciduous woodland with Oak, Sycamore, Beech, Horse Chestnut, Ash, Birch and Alder all being found there. There are also some apple and hawthorn trees. Many of the trees are over 30 years old.

Within and around the woods is a well-developed meadow rich in cowslips, parsley, grass and creeping buttercups and in the autumn the site is rich in fungi. For survey results of the plants and insects found at this site please see the following link.

The area is also part of the North Campus Bumblebee monitoring route and a list of recently found bumblebees can be found here.

Mowing Plan: Cut once in September/October. The edges of the woods and meadow are mown frequently.

properties.Name: Edible Garden
properties.Description:
The MU Edible Garden was established formally in 2021 by Dr Patricia Healy-Kettle (Critical Skills and Sustainable Food and Agriculture Working Group Coordinator). Since its inception, the garden has witnessed significant progress and success thanks to the hard work and dedication of the working group, Green Campus, the MU Enviro Soc and the many volunteers and local community of Maynooth who frequent and engage in the garden.

With the aim of bringing staff, students and wider community of Maynooth together to cultivate fresh healthy produce using sustainable principles, the garden has also greatly contributed to Maynooth Green Campus objectives by enhancing biodiversity and local eco-systems (with over twenty new species recently recorded) and fostering sustainable relationships with land, food and nature by connecting food to human health, well-being and environmental sustainability. In addition to the vegetables and fruits that are planted in the raised beds, the garden also has a collection of native Irish apple trees, plums and raspberries and a recently established wildflower strip.(see the following link for a planting scheme).

For more details on the Edible Garden and the events that take place there see the following link.

Bees

The edible garden is the last stop on the North Campus Bumblebee monitoring Route and is a hotspot for a diversity of insects and birds. For a recent survey of the bumblebees see the following link

Other Insects

The garden is abundant in hoverflies and several butterfly species are commonly found including peacocks, brimstones, small tortoiseshell and green-veined whites. The garden is there for all to use and we welcome your engagement.
